predicate.note: Frames file for 'lock' based on sentences in financial subcorpus. Verbnet class tape-22.4, other framed members include clamp, link, tie.

example.name: passive
example.text: ``Then they said, `By the way, two of the doors are locked.'''

example.name: two things connected
example.text: He said the move toward standard operating systems means customers aren't locked *trace* into buying from their traditional computer supplier and can force prices down.
example.arg: buying from their traditional computer supplier

example.name: with instrument
example.text: John locked his expensive bike with 50 yards of dental floss.

example.name: transitive
example.text: Most other supercomputer manufacturers have yet to adopt the Posix standard, Mr. Paluck said, adding that they prefer to maintain proprietary systems that *trace* lock in customers.

example.name: with attribute
example.text: When it occurs, the traders place orders via computers to buy the basket of stocks in whichever market is cheaper and sell them in the more expensive market; they lock in the difference in price as profit.

example.name: criminal intent
example.text: John was locked up *trace* as a menace to society.

roleset.name: secure

example.name: got it
example.text: In any settlement, Warner is almost certain to demand rights to most of the 50 or so projects *trace* Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters have locked up *trace* for the next few years, notably sequels to ``Batman.''

roleset.note: These two senses are very similar.

example.name: transitive
example.text: The risk is that Jaguar's share price could slump if GM's agreement with Jaguar effectively locks out its U.S. rival.

example.name: oops
example.text: John was locked out *trace* of his house.
